cohort: Founders, startup operators, senior professionals, and early investors aged roughly 28–45 with first-generation wealth or rapid income acceleration, who are comfortable with complexity and allergic to fluff.
userContext: Users are actively thinking about how to turn volatile or fast-growing income into long-term, compounding wealth. They are comparing tools, skeptical of marketing speak, and expect clear, high-signal explanations before committing serious capital.
verdict: Users abandon when asked to share personal information before seeing what they'll get in return.

beliefBreak.irreversibleAction: User must make a commitment at step 1 of 5 (20% progress) without seeing value first.

callouts.text: Sensitive data requested at peak commitment
No established trust before financial disclosure

beliefBreak.psychology: Users arrive expecting to explore options, but immediately encounter a request for personal information. The mismatch between initial expectations and actual requirements triggers immediate abandonment.

userBelieves: This is a quick exploration tool
They can browse options without commitment
The platform will show value before asking for data
productAsks: Make a commitment without seeing value
whyItFails: Value not demonstrated before data request

oneBet.headline: Show personalized recommendations BEFORE requesting financial disclosure.
oneBet.support: If users see tailored results based solely on preferences, establishing value before trust demands, completion rates should increase.

howWrong.name: Value-First Sequencing Test
howWrong.hypothesis: Users abandon due to premature data request, not data request itself
howWrong.measure: Completion rate when financial questions move to post-recommendation vs current placement
howWrong.falsifier: If post-recommendation placement shows equal abandonment, timing isn't the blocker.

howWrong.name: Progressive Disclosure Test
howWrong.hypothesis: Users need gradual trust building through value demonstration
howWrong.measure: Engagement with initial recommendations (no financial data) vs refined recommendations (with data)
howWrong.falsifier: If users don't engage with initial recommendations, they don't value the output.

howWrong.name: Framing Transparency Test
howWrong.hypothesis: Bait-and-switch perception drives exit more than data request
howWrong.measure: Completion rate when step 1 explicitly mentions 'financial info needed' vs silent
howWrong.falsifier: If transparency reduces starts, users actively avoid financial disclosure regardless of timing.

assumptions: Users discovered Novelty Wealth - Investing & Wealth Building through organic search or ads promising 'instant recommendations'
Competing platforms offer immediate results without financial disclosure
Users have not yet established relationship with the brand
constraints: Accurate matching requires some financial data
Lending partners require minimum qualification criteria
rationale: Privacy reassurance appears only AFTER request — too late for trust building
Landing page shows value proposition (9.99% p.a., up to ₹1 Crore) but doesn't show personalized eligibility
Users see generic benefits but must start process to learn if they qualify
Competing platforms show initial matches without credit score disclosure

marginNotes.page2: Note: 20% progress indicator creates expectation of completion, not new high-friction requirement.
marginNotes.page4: High confidence: Pattern observed across fintech onboarding where value-before-trust sequencing improves conversion.
marginNotes.page5: Alternative hypothesis: Users lack credit score knowledge, not willingness to share. Test 'Don't know my score' option.
marginNotes.page3: Landing page promises exploration, but immediately requires personal information — expectation mismatch from the start.
